Piaget to open symposium tomorrow
By JACK COUTEAU
Famed Swiss psychologist Jean
Piaget will speak on "The Nature
of Creativity" in the keynote
address of the sixth annual Milton
S. Eisenhower Symposium
tomorrow at 4 pm in Shriver Hall
Translator
Dr. Piaget will deliver his
address in French, which will be
translated by Eleanor Duckworth
of Halifax, Nova Scotia, the only
woman in North America whom
Piaget allows to translate his
works into English.
Co-chairmen of the

Symposium, juniors Mike Saks
and Harlan Doliner expect an
overflow crowd for the Piaget
lecture. People from Texas to
Canada have called to reserve
places but the 1,200 seats will be
filled on a first come, first serve
basis.
To accommodate the
anticipated excess crowds,
television monitors will be set up
in Shaffer Hall and in the Clipper
Room of Shriver in addition to a
loudspeaker system on the steps
outside the auditorium.
Dr. Piaget is flying from

Geneva especially for this lecture.
Because of his work in child
developmen and learning theory,
he has come to be known as the
"father of educational
psychology."
Future.

Future speakers in the
Symposium include author C.P.
Snow, sociologist Dr. Nathan ,
Glazer, poet Robert Creeley,
New York Times critic Clive
Barnes, composer Aaron
Copeland and architect Moshe

Honor Code seen as desireable
By PETER GARDNER
A great majority of students
and faculty at Johns Hopkins feel
that the: Honor Code is a
desirable part of this university's
education.
According to the second
edition of the Relay, 75% of the
faculty feel that the Honor Code
is a desirable aspect of education
at Johns Hopkins while 84% of
undergraduates feel this way.
Both groups feel that exams
should not be proctored; 79% of
the students disagreed with the
Idea of proctored exams, while
Only 56% of the faculty felt
similarly.
32% of the undergraduates
responding felt that many
students cheat while only 14% of
the faculty felt that the cheating
'Was so widespread. However,
86% of the faculty felt that at
least some students cheat while
Only 67% of the students felt this
way.
A majority of the students
Polled (54%) said that they
would have to consider the
Fircumstances before they turned
in someone for cheating. Only
38% of the faculty said that their
decision would depend on the

circumstances.
Interestingly, only 9% of the
students indicated that they
would automatically report
someone for cheating, while a
majority (57%) of the faculty
said they would do so.
The widest divergence of
student-faculty opinion appears
to be in regard to the relevance
of the Honor Code to college life
today. 3/4 of the faculty felt that
the Honor Code still had
relevance whereas 3% of the
undergraduates felt that it did
not.
In a question answered by

10 admitted that they had ever
violated the Honor Code.
